record.text: What‚Äôs everyone‚Äôs favorite dad movie

value.text: Trying to do a daily dumb little prompt to not think about The Horrors

record.text: I thought a lot of people were going to say master and commander or the hunt for red october but I didn‚Äôt expected them to be a ballpark 50% of the answers
don‚Äôt love to get an unsolicited upwards shot of a bunch of dudes cumming in response to this prompt. v cool buddie
WTAF
*what*

fucksakes!

I'm sorry.
:S
I mean they are also my answers and my spouses so‚Ä¶
M&C was 100% going to be my response so add that to the pile
The thing is M&C is just so dang good
Absolutely came to fulfill the stereotype
The Hunt for Red October was the first one to come to mind, lol
The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Tony Soprano plugged this one and I gave it a shot. It was very good, really tense. It has the conceit of taking place over the 90 minutes or so getting to noon. Has a theme about the importance of community self defense.
Recent and just okay but it checks the boxes
Oh noooooooooooooo, the older one's so much better!
Some variety. Shane is an old school dad movie. Jimmy Stewart's a gunman starting over who befriends a rancher family that reminds him of his lost innocence. Logan was influenced by this one.
*Alan Ladd
But yes.
lmbo at posting a Hunt for Red October quote repost and then seeing this. absolutely owned.
it's a dad movie if boat. (even princess bride has one)
Between M&C and The Hunt for Red October, you gotta go with the lesser of two weevils.
I just came here to say the one ping.
He who would pun would pick a pocket!
I loved master and commander for Big Sail Ship but after introducing my partner to it she pointed out how legitimately good the cinematography is too. It's an all time great
also fun to interpret the violin/cello duets as sex scenes
Look I'm a sucker for tales of wooden ships and iron men.
Oh come on Soviet shipbuilding wasn‚Äôt *that* shoddy
Would you say this business got out of control
wow, you literally said the two i would have said
My dad's "dad movie" was "Lawrence of Arabia," but he loved "Master and Commander" and "The Hunt for Red October," too.
ships of the desert amirite
Looking at the responses and wow, Bond is truly dead.

value.text:
"Boats" is the main thing

Master & Commmander - old boats
Hunt for Red October - underwater boats
Apollo XIII - Space boats

record.text: Top Gun - Sky Boats
(A more accurate 'sky boats' would have been Sky Captain & The World Of Tomorrow but I think the only dad who watched that one was me)
I was just about to say master and commander, even though I‚Äôve only seen it once
I have seen it more times than I want to admit.
I‚Äôll need to set aside an evening for it. Takes a lot of preplanning. Sandwiches and all that.
Master and Commander's not a dad movie... Oh no.
Is the other 50% Shawshank and Die Hard?

Ronin or the fugitive probably next most popular but also way less red october or M&C

I also expected a lot more indiana jones & the last crusade which I think only has two so far
Huh, those are all obvious dad movies that did not occur to me at all.  Which makes it even more surprising those two are far and away the leaders.
Sneakers!

I‚Äôve seen that effort a couple times also..but let‚Äôs just say mom is not a creative performance type.. she ran satellite space launch systems for the AF for a career..so she‚Äôs like an elderly super nerd and thinks on a different level üöÄüòÇ

A bunch of us got super stoned one night in college and watched Casablanca. None of us had ever seen it before or really knew much about it beyond a few quotes. It was perhaps the most enthralled movie watching experience any of us had/have ever had.)

Definitely a Dad movie. But also my wife‚Äôs favorite movie. She had a big crush on Bogie as a kid and legit cried when she learned he was dead and so they could never be together. Glad she settled for :)

external.description: Alt: The three protagonists of "O Brother Where Art Thou," having escaped from a chain gang, just barely failed to catch a passing freight train. Pete and Everett have been arguing over which of them should be in charge. Pete votes for himself. Everett similarly votes for himself. Delmer, the potential tiebreaking vote, thinks for a moment and says "okay, I'm with you fellas."

record.text:
Mine is, and shall always be, SILVERADO. 

It's like an entire d&d campaign in a single film. Each of the four protagonists has his own little arc, and they're unstoppable when they are at last united
Also c'mon when else were you gonna see Kevin Kline, Danny Glover, Jeff Goldblum, and Brian Dennehy in the same picture
‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the dog?‚Äù

That's the other thing! It's a screenwriting masterclass! Everyone's got histories that extend well beyond the confines of the script. Some stuff you learn about, e.g., Paden and the dog. 

Some, you don't, like what Slick's whole deal is
And Linda Hunt!
She only shines at night!
‚ÄúThe world is what you make of it.‚Äù

I feel like everyone has a manner of themed speech, almost like a leitmotif, that sets them apart.

Stella: Make alterations, cherish the Good Stuff
Paden: gambling metaphors, "Deal me in/out", risk-aware and initially risk-averse
Mal: Justice, fairness, "That ain't right."
Cobb: business euphemisms
It should've been a much bigger deal.
T√°r
Hard mode not master and commander I assume
I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs Dad enough
Or Elite Mode which is also no Hunt For Red October.
My husband says the Martian
Which is SPIRITUALLY a Ron Howard film. So yes.
I've never seen anything more true
It's spectacular Competency Porn.
Noticing a theme
Gettysburg. I don't know if the movie was actually a big deal (I think it kind of was?) but it was a HUGE deal to my dad.
Heat

record.text: Or, if that movie has too much romantic plotting to be considered a ‚Äúdad movie‚Äù, then my answer is Jurassic Park (1993). It‚Äôs got dinosaurs, climbing trees, running, Richard Attenborough, exposition and a man taking on the reluctant ‚Äúfather‚Äù role and becoming more responsible in the process.

record.text: My problem is, I'm old enough to be a dad, and when you say "Dad movie", I mostly think of stuff my dad liked, which was mostly old Clint Eastwood westerns and adaptations of John Grisham novels. At this point, that stuff is positively ancient.
Anyway, I'll say The Good, The Bad, and the Ugly since it has a banger soundtrack.

external.description: ALT: a statue of a man in a space suit stands in front of a building
external.title: a statue of a man in a space suit stands in front of a building

external.title: a statue of a man in a space suit stands in front of a building

record.text: Yeah, 50's horror and sci-fi are what I often associate with my dad. Stuff like The Creature from the Black Lagoon and THEM!
I don't know if anyone else would consider it a "dad movie", but the film I most associate with my dad is Heavy Metal.
Hell yeah sister.
This made me laugh and your dad must be awesome.
He's a grumpy old man, but he's my grumpy old man, and I love him.
Is there a definition of a Dad Movie? I guess Sneakers comes the closest, but I‚Äôm not clear on what the necessary elements are?
A River Runs Through It
The Taking of Pelham 123 (1974)
The Abyss is another fine film
Ok, now I‚Äôm confused. I‚Äôm a dad. Are these movies we‚Äôre watching with our kids? Or movies we watched with our dads?
I kind of think of it as a comfort movie a dad would watch. Either by himself or with his kids.
Yes.

In my understanding, Dad Movies are movies with Dad Energy. The protagonist is often a Dad himself, or else a father figure to younger characters. He saves the day through Dad Skills, courage and resourcefulness.
Thank you for clarifying. I can confidently stand by my picks: Heat, The Abyss and (of course) Shawshank Redemption
All three are great choices üëç

I read the prompt differently- I thought it was the kind of movie dads like - typically a western or military movie (esp WWII). The kind of movie that makes everyone groan when he suggests it on family movie night.
The Dirty Dozen is the platonic ideal of this movie

Yeah. It's not exclusive of my Dad Movie theory. The brave, capable leader as protagonist is a slightly old-fashioned way of storytelling, popular in old Westerns and working especially well in war movies.

Fair enough. I'm not some kind of authority here, I'm just having fun.

But I'm intrigued by what makes a Dad Movie. Eg. why is Hunt For Red October generally agreed to be a top example? Why that one, and not some other spy movie? Hence my theory of the Dad Movie protagonist. üòÄ

The key element of a Dad Movie is a protagonist who succeeds by being calm under pressure, providing leadership, and applying practical know-how.

MacGuyver is not in a movie, but he's a prime example of the type.

There's a large overlap with the concept of positive masculinity.
Some of the best Dad Movies have *two* such protagonists: Heat, The Fugitive, The Shawshank Redemption, and (of course) The Hunt For Red October.
This is basically the template for every Stephen King protagonist
There are exceptions (Carrie, The Shining) but by and large, yes. üòÄ
I‚Äôm thinking The Stand, 11/22/63, Under the Dome. All basically the same guy: resourceful, underestimated, between 30 and 40 and white
Yes, fair. And many others: The Dead Zone, Bag of Bones, Mr Mercedes, etc.

The Dad Movie protagonist does not have superhuman abilities. Star Wars, The Matrix, and Dune are enjoyed *by* Dads, but not Dad Movies. James Bond and Batman don't fit either, with their elite training and arsenals of gadgets.

But Sam Gamgee in Peter Jackson's LOTR is absolutely a Dad Movie hero.

external.description: Alt: Hans Gruber in Die Hard says, "You're amazing. You figured this all out already?"
external.title: a man in a suit and tie says you 're amazing

record.text:
Die Hard is another Dad Movie with two main Dad characters.

John McClane, obviously, is literally a Dad who triumphs by courage and ingenuity. But Hans Gruber is a smart, capable, and respected leader -- Evil Dad, if you will. üòà

external.title: a man in a suit and tie says you 're amazing
external.description: Alt: Hans Gruber in Die Hard says, "You're amazing. You figured this all out already?"

record.text: The Dad Movie, of course, provides identification for Dads or those of Dad-like disposition. We know we're not Superman or Axel Foley or James Bond. But we can imagine rising to the occasion like Richard Kimble or Marko Ramius or Andy Dufresne. üòÄ
Wow, this is an excellent analysis.
Heat
Great dad movie that he can't show the kids until they are older
